Catch the exceptions you expect:

try {
    ...
}
catch (IExpectedThisException success) {
    assertEquals(expectedValue, success.getSomeExceptionAttribute());
    ...
}

Throw the exceptions that you don't expect:

public void testEjbs() throws RemoteException, FinderException, ... {
    // EJB code
}

If there's something "in between" where an exception represents a failure,
but not an error, then catch it and fail:

try {
    ...
}
catch (SomeKindOfFailureException oops) {
    fail(oops.toString());
}

That's how I like to do things...

Subject:  [junit] Propagating Exceptions



All/Any,

I'm writing Entity EJB tests.  The setUp(), tearDown() create and destroy
EJBs.  Other test methods do all the - well - testing.  The problem is that
work of this sort throws tons of exceptions which I have been catching in
the methods.  However this means that JUnit doesn't catch those exceptions
and doesn't report well when they occur.

Should I catch those exceptions or should I propagate them out to Junit to
catch in this specific case?

In general how should/must one deal with this issue?

Adam Pelleter
